content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Matthew Stahl: Well, I was born in Chicago, but I grew up in a small town in the East North Central region, which is where I've lived most of my life. My parents were pretty typical for the time—my dad worked in manufacturing, and my mom was a teacher. She had a bachelor's degree, which was pretty rare for women back then, and she always encouraged me and my siblings to value education. I remember growing up in a tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other, and we had a strong sense of community. I went to a public school, and while I wasn't the most academically gifted kid, I was always curious and had a love for learning. I ended up going to college on a scholarship, which was a big deal for my family. I studied political science and later got my master's degree, which helped me land a job in public policy. I met my wife during grad school, and we've been married for about six years now. We have a young daughter, and life has been busy but fulfilling. I consider myself an independent thinker, and I try to stay involved in my community, whether through church or local events.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Matthew Stahl: Yes, there was a defining moment that really shaped the direction of my life. I was about 22, in my second year of college, and I had a choice to make. I had been working part-time at a local community center, helping out with after-school programs for kids from low-income families. It was rewarding work, but I was also struggling with my coursework and feeling uncertain about my future. I had the option to take a gap year and focus on gaining more experience or to push through and finish my degree. My mom, who had always pushed me to value education, encouraged me to stay the course. But I also had a mentor at the community center who saw potential in me and suggested I apply for a graduate assistantship at a local university. That opportunity changed everything. I ended up getting the assistantship, which allowed me to continue my studies while gaining hands-on experience in public policy. That experience not only solidified my passion for the field but also gave me the confidence to pursue a master's degree. Looking back, I think that moment was a crossroads because it forced me to balance my practical needs with my long-term goals, and ultimately, it led me down the path I'm on today.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Matthew Stahl: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. I had to weigh the immediate need for stability against the long-term potential of furthering my education. I remember sitting with my mom one evening, telling her about the assistantship opportunity, and she just looked at me and said, 'If you're meant to be doing something, you'll find a way to make it work.' That really stuck with me. I knew I wanted to make a difference in people's lives, but I also knew I needed the tools to do it effectively. So I made the decision to take the risk, and I've never regretted it. It wasn't just about the job or the degree—it was about aligning my values with my actions, and that's something I've carried with me ever since.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Matthew Stahl: Absolutely, I think I was really lucky to have people in my life who believed in me even when I wasn't entirely sure of myself. My mom was one of them, but I also had that mentor at the community center—his name was Mr. Kowalski. He had a way of making you feel like your ideas mattered, even if you were just starting out. He didn't just hand me the opportunity; he challenged me to apply for it, to step out of my comfort zone. And then there was the university itself, which had a strong public policy program and offered financial support through that assistantship. I think if I hadn't had those supports in place, I might have hesitated longer or maybe even given up on the idea of going to grad school. It's not something you can do alone, and I'm grateful to everyone who helped me take that first step.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Matthew Stahl: Yes, I have a wife named Sarah and a young daughter, Lily. We got married right after I finished my master's degree, and we moved to Evanston so I could take a job with a local nonprofit focused on community development. Sarah is a graphic designer, and she's been incredibly supportive of my work, even though it means we sometimes have to juggle long hours and tight deadlines. Lily is three now, and she's the light of our lives. She's already showing a lot of curiosity, just like I did when I was a kid. We live in a cozy home on Ashland Avenue, and we try to make sure she grows up with the same values my mom instilled in me—like the importance of education, kindness, and giving back to the community. Sarah and I both volunteer at the same community center where I used to work part-time, and it's amazing to see how the place has grown since I was there. It's funny, sometimes I look at Lily and think about how her life will unfold, and I hope she has the same opportunities I did, but even more. Family has always been the foundation of who I am, and I'm grateful every day for the people in my life.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's amazing how the choices we make, even when they feel uncertain at the time, can shape the rest of our lives. Thinking about my childhood, my parents, especially my mom, and the values she instilled in me, I realize how much they influenced the person I am today. The crossroads I faced in college was a pivotal moment that forced me to choose between stability and growth, and I'm glad I took the risk. I'm also reminded of how important it is to have people in your life who believe in you—whether it's family, mentors, or organizations that provide opportunities. Now, as a father, I'm trying to pass on those same values to my daughter, Lily, and I hope she grows up with the same sense of purpose and community that I was lucky enough to have. It's been a journey, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Matthew Stahl: My immediate family includes my parents, Joseph and Anna Stahl, and my younger sister, Elena. My dad, Joseph, worked in manufacturing for most of his life, and while he didn't have a college education, he always made sure we understood the value of hard work and responsibility. He was the kind of guy who would fix anything around the house, from the plumbing to the car, and he taught me how to be resourceful. My mom, Anna, was the heart of our family. She was a teacher, as I mentioned before, and she had a way of making every student feel seen and heard. She passed that same empathy on to me, and I think it's why I ended up in the field I'm in now. Elena is ten years younger than me, and she's always been the adventurous one. She's a nurse now, working in a hospital in Chicago, and I'm really proud of her. We're close, even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like. Family dinners are still a big deal for us, and even though we're all in different stages of life, we always make time for each other. I think that's one of the reasons I'm so committed to raising Lily with the same sense of family and community that I grew up with—it's something I know is worth passing on.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Matthew Stahl: Of course, there are a few friends and mentors who have been really important to me over the years. One person who comes to mind is my college roommate, David. We met in our first year, and even though we took different paths—David went into tech while I pursued public policy—we stayed close. He's always been a good sounding board for me, especially when I was trying to figure out my career direction. Then there's my former boss at the nonprofit I work for now, Maria. She's been a huge influence on me, not just professionally but personally. She's one of those people who leads with empathy and integrity, and I try to model my own leadership after her. I also have a few friends from my church community who have been there for me through good times and bad. They've helped me stay grounded and reminded me of the importance of faith and service. I think the people who stick around in your life are the ones who truly understand you, and I'm lucky to have a lot of them.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Matthew Stahl: I live in Evanston now, and it's a pretty unique place. It's a college town, so there's always a lot of energy and diversity here. The streets are tree-lined, and there's a real sense of community, especially in neighborhoods like the one I'm in on Ashland Avenue. We're close to Lake Michigan, which is a big part of our daily life—Lily loves going to the beach, and we often take walks along the shore. The town has a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there's a strong emphasis on education and the arts. I've always appreciated how welcoming the people here are, and it's not uncommon to see neighbors stopping by to say hello or offer help. There are a lot of local businesses, from cozy cafes to independent bookstores, and the sense of civic engagement is pretty high. It's a place where people care about their community, and I think that's why I chose to live here—it feels like the kind of environment where I can continue to grow both personally and professionally, while also raising Lily in a place that values kindness and opportunity.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Matthew Stahl: I feel very safe here in Evanston. It's not just the low crime rate, though that does help—it's the sense of community and mutual respect that makes this place feel secure. I've never had any issues with my neighbors, and I know they'd do the same for me. There's a kind of unspoken agreement here that we look out for one another, whether it's helping someone carry groceries, keeping an eye on each other's homes when we're away, or just being there for one another in times of need. I think that's one of the things that makes this neighborhood special. It's not just a place to live—it's a place where you feel like you belong, and that kind of belonging goes a long way in making you feel safe.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Matthew Stahl: Living here in Evanston has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. One of the things I appreciate most is the access to cultural and educational opportunities. We're just a short walk from Northwestern University, and there are always events happening—art shows, lectures, even community forums on local issues. It's inspiring to see how engaged people are here. That said, the cost of living can be a bit of a strain, especially with Lily in daycare and the mortgage. We've had to be careful with our budget, but it's manageable. I also miss the slower pace of the small town where I grew up, though I think Evanston offers a different kind of richness. It's a place where you can be both connected and reflective, and I think that balance is what makes it work for us. Overall, I feel lucky to be here, and I hope Lily grows up with the same sense of possibility that I've come to associate with this city.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my roots and environment shape who I am today. Talking about my wife, Sarah, and daughter, Lily, reminded me of how important it is to build a life filled with love, support, and shared values. It also made me think about how lucky I am to live in a place like Evanston, where there's a strong sense of community and safety. It's amazing how the people around us—whether family, friends, or neighbors—can have such a lasting impact on our lives. I feel grateful for the people in my life and the environment I get to raise Lily in, and I hope I can pass on the same sense of belonging and purpose to her as I was given.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Matthew Stahl: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but there's always some variation depending on work and family needs. I usually start my week with a few early mornings—Lily's daycare is right across the street, so I can walk her there while I get some exercise. I work full-time at the nonprofit, so most days involve meetings, project planning, and collaborating with a small team. Mondays are often the busiest, with team check-ins and strategy sessions, while Fridays tend to be a bit more relaxed, especially if there's a community event or something happening at the church. On weekends, we try to keep it family-focused. Sarah and I take turns handling the bulk of the parenting duties, but we both enjoy spending time with Lily—whether it's going to the park, visiting the library, or just having a quiet morning at home. I also make time for my own interests, like reading or going for a run along the lake. There are weeks when I'm pulled in a lot of directions, but I try to keep things balanced so I can be present for both my work and my family. It's not perfect, but it's a rhythm that works for us.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Matthew Stahl: I work full-time at a local nonprofit called the Evanston Community Development Initiative, where I focus on policy research and community engagement. My days typically start around 8:00 a.m., and I work until about 5:00 p.m., though sometimes I stay a bit later if there's a meeting or a project deadline. The job is demanding, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I get to work with a passionate team of people who are all committed to making a difference in our community. A big part of my role involves collaborating with local leaders, attending town halls, and helping to draft proposals for new programs that support affordable housing, education access, and youth development. I also spend a fair amount of time analyzing data and writing reports, which can be a bit tedious, but I find it important for ensuring that our work is grounded in solid evidence. The best part of the job, though, is seeing the impact of our efforts—whether it's a new community center opening or a policy that helps more families access resources they need. I feel lucky to be doing work that aligns with my values, and I try to bring that same sense of purpose into my family life as much as possible.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Matthew Stahl: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to read at least one book a month, usually nonfiction or historical fiction—something that challenges my thinking or gives me a new perspective. I've always been interested in how societies function, which probably stems from my time in college and my career. I also make it a point to go for a run or bike ride along the lake a few times a week. It's not just exercise for me—it's a chance to clear my head and reflect on what's going on in my life. I find that when I'm moving, I can think more clearly, and it helps me stay focused on both my work and my family. Another thing I do is volunteer at the community center a couple of times a month, even though my schedule is busy. It's a way to give back, and it reminds me of where I came from. I think those small, consistent habits are what keep me balanced and connected to the things that matter most.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Matthew Stahl: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing short meditation sessions while I'm getting Lily ready for daycare, and it's been a nice way to start the day with intention. I also began cooking more meals at home instead of relying on takeout, which has been a positive shift for both my health and our family budget. It's funny, though—I didn't think I had time for these things before, but once I made the effort, it became a natural part of my day. I've also been trying to set aside more time for Sarah, whether it's a quiet coffee in the morning or a walk after dinner. It's not about being perfect, but about making sure we're both present for each other and for Lily. These small changes have made a big difference in how I feel overall, and I'm grateful for the little moments that help keep us all grounded.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Matthew Stahl: Lily's typical weekday during the school year starts early—usually around 7:00 a.m., when we get up and have a quick breakfast together. She goes to a local public school, and her school day runs from 8:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. After school, she usually has some time for lunch and recess before heading to after-school activities. Right now, she's involved in a few things: she takes a creative arts class twice a week at the community center, which is where I used to work, and she also has a weekly soccer practice. I love seeing her get excited about these activities—it's amazing how much she's growing and learning. On most days, Sarah and I try to pick her up around 3:30 p.m., and then we have dinner together as a family. After that, we often read a story or play a game before bedtime. It's a busy schedule, but it's also full of love and learning. I think the most important thing is that she feels supported and encouraged to explore her interests, just like I was when I was her age.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my family and neighborhood shape the rhythm of my life. Talking about my wife, Sarah, and daughter, Lily, reminded me of how important it is to build a life filled with love, support, and shared values. It also made me think about how lucky I am to live in a place like Evanston, where there's a strong sense of community and safety. I feel grateful for the people in my life and the environment I get to raise Lily in, and I hope I can pass on the same sense of belonging and purpose to her as I was given.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Matthew Stahl: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty fortunate. I've always been active, whether it was playing sports as a kid or running along the lake now. I don't have any major health issues, but I've had my share of minor things—like the occasional cold or a sprained ankle from playing soccer with Lily. I do make an effort to stay in shape, and I've always believed that a healthy body supports a healthy mind. I've also been lucky to have a good relationship with my doctor, Dr. Patel, who's been with me since I was in college. He's always encouraged me to keep up the good habits and has been a great resource for advice on everything from stress management to nutrition. I've started paying more attention to what I eat, especially since becoming a dad—I want to be around for Lily for a long time. I also try to get enough sleep, though with a busy work schedule and parenting duties, it's not always easy. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I think the combination of staying active, eating well, and having a supportive family has made a big difference in how I feel day to day.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Matthew Stahl: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, living in Evanston gives me access to so many opportunities—whether it's the lake for running, the local parks for family walks, or the community center where I can take yoga classes. I also really enjoy cooking at home, and Sarah and I have started meal prepping on weekends, which helps me stick to healthier eating habits. The support from my family is another big plus—I know they're always cheering me on, whether it's encouraging me to take a break or reminding me to drink more water. On the harder side, though, the demands of work and parenting can make it tough to maintain a strict routine. There are days when I'm so busy that I skip my morning run or grab a coffee on the way to work instead of eating a proper breakfast. I've also struggled with stress, especially when work gets overwhelming, and I have to remind myself to take time for self-care. But I think the key is balance—knowing that I don't have to be perfect, just consistent. I've learned that even small choices, like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or going for a short walk during lunch, can add up over time. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to make health a priority because I know it's the foundation for everything else in life.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Matthew Stahl: In the past two years, I've been pretty healthy overall, but there was one incident that stands out. A few months ago, I was helping Lily set up for a family picnic at the park when I slipped on some wet grass and twisted my ankle. It wasn't a major injury, but it hurt enough to keep me off my feet for a few days. I had to take a couple of days off work, which was a bit stressful since we were in the middle of a big project. I saw Dr. Patel, and he gave me a brace and some physical therapy exercises. It was a reminder that even small things can disrupt your routine, but it also made me more mindful of how I move and take care of my body. I've since been more careful, especially when I'm around Lily, and I've started doing some balance exercises to prevent anything like that from happening again. It wasn't a big health event, but it was a wake-up call to stay vigilant about my well-being.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Matthew Stahl: Honestly, I think that incident with my ankle was a good reminder of how fragile things can be, even when you're used to being active and careful. I didn't miss work for long, and I was able to catch up on the project, but it did make me think about how much I rely on my body to keep up with the demands of work and parenting. I know there are people for whom health issues can be far more disruptive—whether it's chronic pain, long-term illness, or something that limits their ability to work or care for their families. I feel lucky that my situation was minor, but it also made me more aware of how important it is to take care of myself so I can be there for Lily and Sarah. I don't take that for granted anymore.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Matthew Stahl: Over the past year, I've felt a lot of gratitude and a deep sense of purpose, but also some moments of quiet uncertainty. Life has been busy with work, family, and trying to keep up with Lily's growing curiosity and energy. There were times when I felt overwhelmed, especially during the pandemic surge last winter, when everything felt a bit more fragile. I remember staying up late one night, watching Lily sleep and thinking about how fast she's growing. It's amazing how much she's changed in just a year—more confident, more inquisitive, and more independent. At the same time, I've been reflecting a lot on my own journey, especially as I've been mentoring some of the younger staff at the nonprofit. It's funny how the lessons I learned from my mom and my mentors have come full circle. I've also been trying to be more present in small ways—whether it's listening more carefully to Sarah, or taking a moment to really notice the beauty in our neighborhood. I think I've been feeling more grounded than ever before, even with all the challenges. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm exactly where I'm meant to be.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits shape the rhythm of my life. Talking about my routines, from mindfulness practices to meal prepping, reminded me of how small, intentional changes can have a big impact on well-being. It also made me think about how important it is to stay active, not just for my body, but for my mind and spirit. The incident with my ankle was a humbling reminder that even the healthiest people can face unexpected challenges, and it made me more mindful of how I take care of myself. I've come to realize that health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about being present, being strong for my family, and living with purpose. I'm grateful for the support of my family and the community around me, and I hope to continue making choices that keep me grounded and healthy for Lily and for myself.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Matthew Stahl: I think I've been fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way that some people do, but I wouldn't say I've been completely free of it. There have been moments—especially during the pandemic—when I felt a bit disconnected, like the world was moving too fast and I wasn't sure where I fit in. I remember one night, after a particularly long week at work, I sat on the porch with a cup of coffee and just stared out at the lake for a while. It wasn't sadness exactly, but more like a quiet exhaustion, a feeling that I was carrying more than I could handle. I think that's something a lot of people go through, especially when you're juggling work, family, and trying to stay present in all of it. What helped me was talking to Sarah, and also leaning on my faith. I've always found comfort in my Catholic beliefs, and I think that sense of connection to something bigger than myself has been a real anchor. I also started journaling more, which helped me process my thoughts and feelings in a way I hadn't before. I don't think I've ever been diagnosed with anything serious, but I do believe that mental health is just as important as physical health, and I'm learning to take it more seriously every day.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Matthew Stahl: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and growth. Sarah has been doing a lot of juggling on her end too—her work as a graphic designer has been busy, and she's taken on more freelance projects to keep us afloat financially. We've had to be really intentional about our time together, and I think that's actually made us closer. Lily has been going through her own little changes too—she's becoming more independent, which is both exciting and a bit overwhelming at times. There were moments when I felt like we were all just trying to keep up with each other, but I think we've found a rhythm. We've leaned on each other more than ever, and I think that's what has kept us grounded. I know it's not perfect, but I feel like we're all learning how to be more present for one another, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Matthew Stahl: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life, though I wouldn't say it's the only thing that defines me. Growing up Catholic, I was raised with a strong sense of community, morality, and the importance of service to others. My mom was a teacher, and she made sure that faith wasn't just something we practiced on Sunday—it was woven into the way we treated each other every day. I still find comfort in the rituals of the Church, like attending Mass on Sundays or participating in the sacraments. It's not just about belief for me; it's about connection—to God, to my family, and to the people in my community. I think faith has given me a sense of purpose, especially as a father. When I look at Lily and think about the kind of person I want her to be, I know that the values I was raised with—like kindness, humility, and compassion—are the ones I want to pass on. I also find that being part of a faith community helps me stay grounded, especially during the busier times in my life. There are days when I feel like I'm not doing enough, or when the world feels too big to navigate, and in those moments, I turn to my faith for strength. It's not perfect, and I know there are people who have different views, but for me, it's been a source of stability and meaning throughout my life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Matthew Stahl: To be honest, I don't use social media very much. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or phone calls over scrolling through feeds. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, but I don't spend a lot of time on it. I find that when I'm on social media, it can be easy to get caught up in comparing yourself to others or getting distracted from the things that matter most. I've tried using Instagram a little bit, but I always end up feeling like I'm missing out on real moments instead of capturing them. Sarah, on the other hand, is more active online—she uses it for her work and to connect with other designers. I respect that, but for me, I think there's something to be said for being present in the moment, whether it's with Lily, at church, or just enjoying the quiet of a Sunday morning. I don't think I've ever felt the need to document every part of my life online, and I think that's okay. There's value in having a life that's lived, not just shared.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Matthew Stahl: Honestly, I don't think I've ever relied on social media for emotional or financial support. I've always found that the people in my life—my family, my friends, my church community—are more than enough to help me through tough times. There's something about knowing that someone is just a phone call away, or that you can show up at someone's door without needing a screen to connect. I know not everyone has that kind of support system, and I'm not saying social media isn't useful for some people. But for me, it's not something I've needed. When I've gone through hard moments, it's been the people I've known for years, the ones who've walked beside me through life's ups and downs, who have been there. I think that's why I'm not drawn to those platforms—they don't offer the kind of real, meaningful connection that matters most.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how health, both physical and mental, plays a crucial role in the rhythm of everyday life. Talking about my recent ankle injury reminded me that even small setbacks can disrupt the balance we work so hard to maintain, but it also reinforced the importance of being mindful of my body and taking care of myself. It was also a moment of honesty about my mental health—admitting that there have been times when I've felt disconnected or overwhelmed, even if I haven't struggled with serious depression or anxiety. I think it's important to acknowledge those feelings without letting them define me, and I've found that leaning on my faith, my family, and even simple practices like journaling can help me stay grounded. I've come to see health not just as the absence of illness, but as a way of being present in life, for my family, for my work, and for the community I care so much about. I'm grateful for the support I have and for the small, intentional choices I make to stay healthy and whole.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Matthew Stahl: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have fluctuated, but overall, I feel more equipped to handle them than I used to. There were definitely times when work felt overwhelming, especially with the demands of leading a team and trying to stay on top of policy changes. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One thing that's helped me is my daily mindfulness practice—those short meditation sessions in the morning have become a real anchor for me. I also find that talking things through with Sarah has been incredibly grounding. She's my biggest supporter, and I know I can always count on her to listen without judgment. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions in a way that feels productive. There are still days when I feel the weight of everything, but I've learned to be kinder to myself and to recognize that it's okay to not have all the answers. I think the biggest shift has been in how I view stress—not as something to eliminate, but as a part of life that I can navigate with intention and support.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Matthew Stahl: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to Lily's daycare, our mortgage, and groceries. Daycare is a significant part of our budget because Sarah and I both work full-time, and we need reliable care so we can focus on our jobs. The mortgage is another big one—living in Evanston means the cost of housing is pretty high, even though we're in a nice neighborhood. Groceries have also been a bit of a challenge lately, especially with Lily's growing appetite and the fact that we try to eat healthy meals at home. We also have some recurring expenses like car payments, insurance, and utilities. To manage, we've been really careful with our spending—meal prepping on weekends, using coupons, and only buying what we need. I also try to contribute by working extra hours when possible, and Sarah has taken on some freelance design work to help cover unexpected costs. It's not always easy, but we've found a way to make it work, and I feel lucky that we have the support of our community and each other to help us through.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Matthew Stahl: Our household spent roughly around $4,500 last month, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend. The breakdown is pretty consistent—about $1,200 on Lily's daycare, $1,500 on the mortgage, $800 on groceries, and then another $600 or so on car payments, insurance, and utilities. We also have some variable expenses, like occasional family outings or unexpected repairs, but we've been pretty careful to keep those in check. I think the key for us has been prioritizing what matters most—like Lily's care and our home—and being intentional about where we spend our money. We've also started using budgeting apps to track our expenses, which has helped us stay on top of things. It's not always perfect, but we've found a rhythm that works for us, and I feel lucky that we've been able to manage without too much stress.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Matthew Stahl: We rent our home, actually. It's a two-bedroom apartment on Ashland Avenue, and while it's not huge, it feels cozy and functional for our family. Renting has been a practical choice for us, especially with the way the real estate market is here in Evanston. Buying a home would be a big financial commitment, and with Lily still being so young, we wanted to keep our options open in case we needed to move for work or other opportunities. Plus, renting allows us to be in a central location that's close to everything—daycare, the community center, the lake, and even the university. It's not perfect, but it works for us, and we've been lucky to find a place that feels like home.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Matthew Stahl: Over the past year, our bills have definitely had their ups and downs, depending on the season and what's going on in our lives. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up a bit, which is something we're used to, but it still adds up. Then there's the summer, when we use more electricity for air conditioning and we tend to spend a little more on groceries because we're eating more meals at home and trying to keep Lily cool and comfortable. Holidays also bring some changes—like Christmas, when we have to buy gifts, decorations, and maybe go out to dinner with family. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like a new toy for Lily that we didn't plan for, or a sudden repair on the apartment's water heater. But overall, we've been pretty good at managing these fluctuations by setting aside some money each month for unexpected costs. I think the biggest thing that's helped us is being intentional about what we spend and where we spend it. It's not always easy, but we've learned to adjust as needed and stay flexible with our budget throughout the year.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how my family and faith have been my greatest sources of support, especially during challenging times. Talking about my family's experiences over the past year reminded me of how much we've grown together, even when life felt overwhelming. It also made me think about how deeply my Catholic faith has shaped my values and the way I approach both my work and my role as a father. I've come to realize that while social media may offer connection for some, I find my strength in the real, meaningful relationships I have with my wife, daughter, friends, and church community. I'm grateful for the support system I've built and the values I was raised with, which continue to guide me through life's ups and downs.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Matthew Stahl: I think we've always tried to save in a way that makes sense for our family's needs. We have a savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. It's not about having a huge emergency fund, but more about being prepared for the unexpected—like a car repair, a sudden medical expense, or even just a few months of extra daycare costs if something comes up. I also try to save a little bit for Lily's future, even if it's just a few dollars each week. It's not a lot, but it's something. Sarah and I have also been talking about starting a college fund for her, though we're still figuring out the best way to do that without putting too much strain on our budget. I think the key for us has been consistency—saving a little bit regularly, rather than trying to save a lot all at once. It's not perfect, but it gives us peace of mind knowing that we're at least trying.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Matthew Stahl: For us, saving has been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. We've been focusing on building a small emergency fund, which has been especially important given how unpredictable life can be with a young child and full-time jobs. I think the biggest thing we've saved for in the last year has been Lily's future—whether it's small contributions to a college fund or just setting aside money for her education in general. We also try to save a little each month for things like family trips or special occasions, even if it's just a few dollars here and there. It's not about having a lot, but more about being responsible and making sure we're not caught off guard when something comes up. I know we could be saving more, but I think what we're doing now is a good start, and it's something we can build on as our financial situation becomes more stable.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Matthew Stahl: My occupation has been as a policy researcher and community engagement specialist at the Evanston Community Development Initiative, which is a local nonprofit focused on improving the quality of life for residents through education, housing, and youth development programs. In this role, my most important activities involve conducting research on local policy issues, collaborating with community leaders to identify needs, and helping to draft proposals for new initiatives. I also spend a lot of time engaging with residents through town halls, surveys, and one-on-one conversations to make sure their voices are heard in the decision-making process. One of the most rewarding parts of my work is seeing the impact of our efforts—whether it's a new community center opening, a policy that helps more families access resources, or simply knowing that we've made someone feel heard. I think what drives me is the belief that policy should serve people, not just institutions, and I try to bring that philosophy into everything I do. It's not always easy work—there are days when it feels like we're fighting an uphill battle—but I find purpose in knowing that what we do can make a real difference in people's lives, especially for those who are most in need.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Matthew Stahl: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the projects we're working on. Some weeks are more structured, with clear start and end times, while others require me to stay late or come in early to meet deadlines or prepare for meetings. I've always believed in giving my full attention to the work I do, especially since it's something that directly impacts the community we serve. There are days when I'm in the office from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., and others when I'm working from home or meeting with stakeholders in the evening. I've learned to be flexible with my schedule, and I try to make sure that I'm not just checking off tasks, but actually engaging with the people and issues that matter most. It's a balance, but one I'm comfortable with because I know that what I do helps make a difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Matthew Stahl: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, especially since I've been working full-time in public policy. There were a few years in college when I worked part-time at the community center, but that was more of a stepping stone than a second job. After I got my master's and started working at the nonprofit, I made the conscious decision to commit fully to that role because I knew how important it was to be present for both my work and my family. I think having multiple jobs can be overwhelming, especially when you're trying to build a life and raise a child. I've been lucky to have a job that's meaningful and offers some flexibility, so I don't feel the need to take on extra work. I do occasionally take on side projects or volunteer opportunities, but those are more about giving back than making extra money. It's not about the amount of work I do—it's about the impact I can have and the time I can spend with Sarah and Lily.

Going through the interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my stress levels and emotional coping strategies have evolved over the past year, and how my family and faith continue to be my greatest sources of support. Talking about my stress and how I manage it reminded me of the importance of mindfulness, journaling, and leaning on Sarah for guidance and comfort. It also made me think about how my household manages its finances and how we've learned to be intentional with our spending, even as we navigate the challenges of raising a young child and maintaining a stable income. I feel grateful for the balance we've found in our lives—between work, family, and personal well-being—and I'm reminded that it's okay to not have everything figured out, as long as I'm making progress and staying grounded in what truly matters.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Matthew Stahl: In total, our household made roughly around $6,500 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary at the nonprofit and Sarah's freelance design work. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and give us a little breathing room. I think what's most important is that we're both working in fields we care about, and that we're able to provide for Lily and each other. I know we could be earning more, but I don't think money is the only measure of success for us. It's about being able to live with purpose, raise a child with love and stability, and contribute to the community we're a part of. I'm grateful for the work we do and the life we've built together.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Matthew Stahl: I've been at the Evanston Community Development Initiative for about four years now, and it's been a journey of growth both professionally and personally. One of the biggest benefits of the job is the health insurance—it covers me, Sarah, and Lily, which is a huge relief, especially with a young child. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which is something I've come to appreciate more as a parent. There's also a generous retirement plan, which is something I didn't think about much when I first started, but now I'm glad we have it. Another thing I really value is the flexibility the job offers. While I do have a standard workweek, there are times when I can work from home or adjust my hours to accommodate family needs, which has been especially helpful with Lily's schedule. I think the most important benefit, though, is the sense of purpose that comes with the work. Knowing that what I do helps make a difference in people's lives—it's what keeps me motivated and grounded, even on the busiest days.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Matthew Stahl: My relationships at work are pretty much what I'd hope for—supportive, collaborative, and built on mutual respect. My manager, Maria, has been a huge influence on me. She's one of those leaders who leads by example, and she's always been encouraging of my ideas, even when I'm still learning. I remember early on, when I was still figuring out my role, she took the time to sit down with me and talk through my concerns, which really helped me feel confident in my work. As for my coworkers, we're all pretty tight-knit. We've been through a lot together—late nights, tight deadlines, and even some personal challenges—and that shared experience has created a real sense of camaraderie. I think the best part is that we all care about the work we do and the impact it has on the community. It's not just about showing up—it's about showing up with purpose, and I feel lucky to be part of a team that shares that same mindset.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Matthew Stahl: In terms of predictability, my work schedule is pretty consistent, though there's always room for flexibility depending on the needs of the team and the projects we're working on. I usually start around 8:00 a.m. and finish around 5:00 p.m., but there are days when I stay a bit later to wrap up a report or prepare for a meeting. What I appreciate most is that the organization understands the importance of work-life balance, especially for people with families. I can often adjust my hours if needed—whether it's leaving a little early to pick up Lily from daycare or working from home when I need to be more present for Sarah or Lily. That flexibility has been a real blessing, especially as a father. It allows me to be there for the important moments without feeling like I'm constantly choosing between work and family. I think that balance is something I've worked hard to maintain, and it's one of the reasons I feel so connected to my job and the people I work with.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Matthew Stahl: Overall, I feel pretty good about our financial situation, though I know there's always room for improvement. We're not living extravagantly, but we're managing to cover our basic needs and even have a little extra for things like family outings or unexpected expenses. I think the key for us has been being intentional with our spending and making sure we're both working in fields we care about. It's not about having a lot of money—it's about having enough to live with dignity, provide for Lily, and contribute to the community we're part of. I know we could be earning more, but I don't think money is the only measure of success for us. What matters most is that we're building a life that's meaningful, stable, and filled with love. I'm grateful for the work we do and the life we've created together, and I feel like we're on the right path, even if it's not always easy.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how the ebb and flow of our household finances shape the way we live and plan for the future. Talking about how our bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of being adaptable and prepared for the unexpected—whether it's a higher heating bill in the winter or a sudden repair in the summer. It also made me think about how we've learned to manage our budget with intention, prioritizing what truly matters, like Lily's care and our home, while still finding ways to save for the future. I'm grateful for the stability we've built, even with the challenges that come with raising a young child and working full-time. It's not always easy, but I feel like we're making progress, and that gives me a sense of peace knowing we're doing our best to create a secure and meaningful life for our family.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Matthew Stahl: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their roles were quite different. My dad worked in manufacturing for most of his life, and he was always the kind of guy who put in long hours at the factory, coming home tired but always making sure we had what we needed. He didn't have a college education, but he was resourceful and hardworking, and he taught me the value of responsibility and perseverance. My mom, on the other hand, was a teacher, and she worked full-time while also managing the household. She had a bachelor's degree, which was pretty rare for women back then, and she always encouraged me and my siblings to value education. Even though she was busy with work and family, she made sure we felt supported and challenged. Looking back, I think their work ethic and the balance they found between career and family had a huge impact on me. It showed me that it's possible to build a life that's both stable and meaningful, and I try to carry that same sense of purpose into my own work and family life today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Matthew Stahl: My dad worked in manufacturing at a local plant, and his most important duties involved operating heavy machinery and ensuring that production lines ran smoothly. He was known for his attention to detail and his ability to troubleshoot problems on the factory floor. He didn't have a college education, but he was always learning—whether it was fixing things around the house or figuring out how to improve his workflow at work. He had a strong work ethic and always made sure we had what we needed, even if it meant working long hours or taking on extra shifts. My mom, on the other hand, was a teacher at a public school, and her most important activities involved planning lessons, engaging with students, and fostering a classroom environment where every child felt valued. She had a way of making complex subjects accessible and exciting, and she always encouraged us to ask questions and think critically. Even though she was busy with work and family, she made sure we felt supported and challenged. Looking back, I think their work ethic and the balance they found between career and family had a huge impact on me. It showed me that it's possible to build a life that's both stable and meaningful, and I try to carry that same sense of purpose into my own work and family life today.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Matthew Stahl: My dad worked for a medium-sized manufacturing company that produced automotive parts. It was one of those old-school factories where the smell of metal and oil was always in the air. He was a machine operator, and his job involved running and maintaining the equipment that turned raw materials into finished products. It wasn't the kind of work that required a college degree, but it was skilled work that required precision, patience, and a real understanding of how the machines worked. He had a way of making even the most complicated machinery feel like an extension of his body. As for my mom, she worked for the local school district, and her job was more than just teaching—it was about shaping young minds. She taught middle school science, and I remember how excited she got when her students asked questions or came up with new ideas. She always said that teaching wasn't just about passing on knowledge, but about inspiring curiosity. I think that's why I ended up in the field I'm in now—because I believe that policy, like education, is about making a difference in people's lives, one idea at a time.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Matthew Stahl: Looking a few years ahead, I hope that Lily continues to grow into the kind of person who is curious, compassionate, and driven to make a difference in the world. I hope she has the same opportunities I did—access to education, a strong support system, and the freedom to explore her passions without fear. I also hope that Sarah and I continue to build a life that's filled with love, purpose, and a sense of community. I'd like to see us settle into a more stable financial position, maybe even buy a home someday, but more than that, I want us to keep growing together as a family. I hope I'm still doing work that matters, that I'm still learning, and that I'm still able to contribute to the community in meaningful ways. I think the most important thing is that we stay grounded in the values that have carried us this far—kindness, hard work, and the belief that everyone deserves a chance to thrive. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with moments that make us feel grateful for the life we've built.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Matthew Stahl: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my community, or the people I work with. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of everyday life, but what keeps me grounded is knowing that I have people who care about me and that I can, in turn, care about them. My relationship with Sarah and Lily is the foundation of everything, and I value the love, laughter, and support we share every day. I also value the sense of purpose that comes from my work—knowing that what I do, even in small ways, can make a difference in someone else's life. And then there's the community I live in, the people who have stood by me through good times and bad. I think it's those connections, both big and small, that give life meaning. I don't think I could ask for anything more than what I have, and I'm grateful every day for the people and values that shape my life.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my work and family life are deeply intertwined, and how the stability and flexibility of my job at the Evanston Community Development Initiative have allowed me to balance both. Talking about our household income and how we manage our finances reminded me of the importance of being intentional with money, not just for survival, but for creating a life that supports our values and our daughter's future. It also made me think about how lucky I am to have a job that offers not just a paycheck, but also health benefits, paid time off, and a sense of purpose. My relationships at work—especially with my manager, Maria, and my coworkers—have been a source of support and growth, and I'm grateful for the collaborative and respectful environment we've built. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm exactly where I'm meant to be, both professionally and personally.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the interviewer but for me as well. It's amazing how the choices we make—whether in our childhood, education, career, or family life—shape the person we become. Thinking back on my early years in that small town, the influence of my parents, especially my mom's dedication to education and kindness, has had a lasting impact on the values I hold today. The crossroads I faced in college, choosing between stability and growth, was a pivotal moment that set me on the path I'm on now. It's humbling to see how the support of mentors like Mr. Kowalski and the opportunities provided by institutions played a role in my development. Now, as a father, I'm trying to pass on the same sense of purpose and community to Lily, knowing how much those values meant to me growing up. My work in public policy, my relationships with Sarah and my coworkers, and even the daily routines I've built with my family all tie back to the person I've become. This reflection has reminded me that life is not just a series of events, but a tapestry woven from the choices we make, the people who support us, and the values we hold dear. I'm grateful for the journey I've been on and for the life I've built with the people I love.
